segment.source: This section includes topics that explain programming concepts that are generally applicable to any app that you write.
segment.target: This section includes topics that explain programming concepts that are generally applicable to any app that you write.

segment.source: XAML platform
segment.target: XAML platform

segment.source: XAML platform
segment.target: XAML platform

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This section includes topics that explain programming concepts that are generally applicable to any app that you write, if you are using C#, Microsoft Visual Basic, or Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX) as your programming language and XAML for your UI definition.
segment.target: This section includes topics that explain programming concepts that are generally applicable to any app that you write, if you are using C#, Microsoft Visual Basic, or Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX) as your programming language and XAML for your UI definition.

segment.source: This includes basic programming concepts such as using properties and events, and how these apply to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app programming.
segment.target: This includes basic programming concepts such as using properties and events, and how these apply to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app programming.

segment.source: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) extends C#, Visual Basic, or C++/CX concepts of properties and their values by adding the dependency property system.
segment.target: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) extends C#, Visual Basic, or C++/CX concepts of properties and their values by adding the dependency property system.

segment.source: Topics in this section also document the XAML language as it is used by the UWP, and cover basic scenarios and advanced topics explaining how to use XAML to define the UI for your UWP app.
segment.target: Topics in this section also document the XAML language as it is used by the UWP, and cover basic scenarios and advanced topics explaining how to use XAML to define the UI for your UWP app.

segment.source: Topic
segment.target: Topic

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: XAML overview
segment.target: XAML overview

segment.source: We introduce the XAML language and XAML concepts to the Windows Runtime app developer audience, and describe the different ways to declare objects and set attributes in XAML as it is used for creating a Windows Runtime app.
segment.target: We introduce the XAML language and XAML concepts to the Windows Runtime app developer audience, and describe the different ways to declare objects and set attributes in XAML as it is used for creating a Windows Runtime app.

segment.source: Dependency properties overview
segment.target: Dependency properties overview

segment.source: This topic explains the dependency property system that is available when you write a Windows Runtime app using C++, C#, or Visual Basic along with XAML definitions for UI.
segment.target: This topic explains the dependency property system that is available when you write a Windows Runtime app using C++, C#, or Visual Basic along with XAML definitions for UI.

segment.source: Custom dependency properties
segment.target: Custom dependency properties

segment.source: Explains how to define and implement custom dependency properties for a Windows Runtime app using C++, C#, or Visual Basic.
segment.target: Explains how to define and implement custom dependency properties for a Windows Runtime app using C++, C#, or Visual Basic.

segment.source: Attached properties overview
segment.target: Attached properties overview

segment.source: Explains the concept of an attached property in XAML, and provides some examples.
segment.target: Explains the concept of an attached property in XAML, and provides some examples.

segment.source: Custom attached properties
segment.target: Custom attached properties

segment.source: Explains how to implement a XAML attached property as a dependency property and how to define the accessor convention that is necessary for your attached property to be usable in XAML.
segment.target: Explains how to implement a XAML attached property as a dependency property and how to define the accessor convention that is necessary for your attached property to be usable in XAML.

segment.source: Events and routed events overview
segment.target: Events and routed events overview

segment.source: We describe the programming concept of events in a Windows Runtime app, when using C#, Visual Basic or C++/CX as your programming language, and XAML for your UI definition.
segment.target: We describe the programming concept of events in a Windows Runtime app, when using C#, Visual Basic or C++/CX as your programming language, and XAML for your UI definition.

segment.source: You can assign handlers for events as part of the declarations for UI elements in XAML, or you can add the handlers in code.
segment.target: You can assign handlers for events as part of the declarations for UI elements in XAML, or you can add the handlers in code.

segment.source: Windows Runtime supports routed events: certain input events and data events can be handled by objects beyond the object that fired the event.
segment.target: Windows Runtime supports routed events: certain input events and data events can be handled by objects beyond the object that fired the event.

segment.source: Routed events are useful when you define control templates, or use pages or layout containers.
segment.target: Routed events are useful when you define control templates, or use pages or layout containers.
